Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: ECR EIE DCL: The Influence of an Inclusive Climate on STEM Academic Early-Career Outcomes

Division.LongName: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers from the University of Michigan Ann Arbor will collaborate with researchers from Michigan State University to implement an EHR Core Research (ECR) project. The project will study how an inclusive educational and workplace climate can affect academic STEM career outcomes, particularly for early-career individuals from underrepresented groups. The proposers will develop a novel construct of inclusive authorship climate in which intellectual contributions are fully welcomed and valued throughout the research process. The proposers will examine inclusive climate at the levels of the research group, department, and profession, each of which likely shapes career outcomes for underrepresented, early-career STEM scholars. Ultimately, this project will advance understanding of how to promote diversity, equity, and inclusion in STEM.

The study builds on the organizational theory of Person-Environment Fit (PE Fit) which claims that career outcomes and attitudes are positively affected by having an organizational environment that is congruent with an individualâ€™s needs, skills, and values. The proposers argue that for individuals in STEM from underrepresented groups, 'fit' requires an inclusive climate (i.e., an environment that values differences and makes all feel welcome). The researchers will develop, test and implement a survey of 3,500 graduate students, postdoctoral scholars, and assistant professors in four STEM fields for which faculty racial minority representation is low and gender representation is low or moderate: physics, economics, biology, and psychology. Structural equation modeling will quantify differences in the effect of inclusive climate on career outcomes of scholars at three different career stages, in departments with different institutional prestige, and in disciplines with different norms and cultures. An important contribution of this research will be the development of the inclusive authorship climate concept and the development of metrics and survey instruments to measure it.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our research goal was to investigate the impact of organizational climate within research groups, departments, and disciplines on career and life outcomes for early-career science scholars in academia. We drew on an organizational theory called Person-Environment Fit to examine how career outcomes and attitudes are affected by having an organizational environment that is congruent with one's needs, skills, and values. This "fit" involves an inclusive climate that values differences across social groups and makes everyone feel welcome. We studied how not having an inclusive climate may be a key contributor to the underrepresentation of scholars from marginalized groups. 

We studied the experiences of early-career scholars--doctoral students, postdoctoral researchers, and assistant professors--from 124 departments of biology, economics, physics, and psychology at 94 PhD-granting institutions across the United States. With a 33% response rate, we had a total of 3,512 early-career scholars who participated in our survey via email between April and May 2021. The survey included measures of participants' demographic characteristics, educational and professional backgrounds, perceptions of inclusive climates, and workplace attitudes and outcomes (e.g., burnout, turnover intentions, productivity). Due to the timing of the survey, we also included questions about the possible impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on scholars' academic outcomes.

The study led to four key findings. First, early-career scholars from marginalized groups reported more negative COVID-related work impacts, including decreased research progress, increased workload, increased concern about career advancement, and increased work disruptions due to mental health problems. Specifically, those who reported a physical, mental, or learning disability experienced more negative work impacts compared to those without a disability. Additionally, underrepresented racial minorities, women, and non-binary scholars reported more negative work disruptions than their majoritized counterparts. Altogether, our findings indicate that the COVID-19 pandemic had a disproportionately negative impact on scholars from marginalized groups (Douglas et al., 2022, PlosOne). 

Second, we found that early-career scholars from marginalized groups viewed climate within their research group, department, and profession more negatively than those from more privileged groups. Specifically, scholars from marginalized groups reported less psychological safety and more intragroup conflict within their research group, lower support for diversity in their academic departments, and lower sense of inclusion within their professional field (Douglas et al., 2024, Journal of Diversity in Higher Education).

Third, scholars' differential climate experiences had important implications for career attitudes and outcomes. Specifically, scholars from marginalized groups reported higher levels of turnover intentions, burnout disengagement, and burnout exhaustion, which were explained by their more negative experiences of the academic climate at all three levels (Douglas et al., 2024, Journal of Diversity in Higher Education).

Fourth, we developed a new construct, authorship climate, which captures individuals' perceptions of fairness around authorship in their scientific teams. We found that perceptions of authorship climate varied according to a number of factors; for example, it was perceived more negatively by scholars earlier in their career, scholars in fields with fewer women, and scholars from marginalized groups (Douglas et al., 2024, Accountability in Research). 

Intellectual Merit

This study conceptualized organizational climate, specifically inclusive climate, as an indicator of fit that is necessary for the success of early-career scholars. Inclusive climates within research groups, departments, and professions are important factors for understanding individuals' career outcomes, especially for those from marginalized groups. We introduced the novel construct of authorship climate as shaping career outcomes of scholars in academic sciences, providing an important new avenue for investigating scholars' experiences with publishing. Finally, our project examined scholars' experiences related to their membership in multiple marginalized groups, allowing us to better capture their lived experiences. Our project suggests that interventions to address poor climate may help achieve goals of increasing diversity and retention in the sciences.

Broader Impacts

The findings from this project have been published in journals in multiple disciplines and have been presented at a variety of professional conferences, symposia, and university colloquia. We also developed reports for each of the study disciplines to more widely share our findings beyond traditional academic outlets. Those reports are available on our webpage and shared with departments and professional societies for the fields of biology, economics, physics, and psychology. It is our hope that these dissemination efforts can help to create more inclusive climates, and in turn increase the success of scholars from marginalized groups in academic STEM.
